# About
**Lab:** Appendix: Producing and Consuming Apache Kafka Messages
**Objective:** Use Kafka's command line tool to create a Kafka topic. Also, use the command line producer and consumer clients to publish and read messages.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Setup

msg.data: Setup

paragraphs.title: Open two terminals
paragraphs.text:
%md

Terminal 1 - create topics and publish data
Terminal 2 - consume data

msg.data:
Terminal 1 - create topics and publish data
Terminal 2 - consume data

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Lab

msg.data: Lab

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Creating a Kafka Topic

msg.data: Creating a Kafka Topic

paragraphs.title: 1 - In terminal 1 display the Kafka topics
paragraphs.text:
%md
Display all Kafka topics to confirm that the new topic you just created is listed

```xml
kafka-topics --list \
    
```

msg.data:
Display all Kafka topics to confirm that the new topic you just created is listed

kafka-topics --list \

paragraphs.title: 2 - Create a Kafka topic for weblogs
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a Kafka topic named weblogs that will contain messages representing lines in Loudacre's web server logs.

```xml
kafka-topics --create \
    
    
    --topic weblogs
```

You will see the message: Created topic "weblogs".

**Note:** If you previously worked on an exercise that used Kafka, you may get an error here indicating that this topic already exists. You may disregard the error.

msg.data:
Create a Kafka topic named weblogs that will contain messages representing lines in Loudacre's web server logs.

kafka-topics --create \


    --topic weblogs

You will see the message: Created topic “weblogs”.

Note: If you previously worked on an exercise that used Kafka, you may get an error here indicating that this topic already exists. You may disregard the error.

paragraphs.title: 3 - List the Kafka topics
paragraphs.text:
%md
Display all Kafka topics to confirm that the new topic you just created is listed

~~~xml
kafka-topics  \
    
~~~

msg.data:
Display all Kafka topics to confirm that the new topic you just created is listed

kafka-topics  \

paragraphs.title: 4 - Review the details of the weblogs topic
paragraphs.text:
%md
```xml
kafka-topics  weblogs \
    

```

msg.data: kafka-topics  weblogs \

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Producing and Consuming Messages

You will now use Kafka command line utilities to start producers and consumers for the topic created earlier.

msg.data:
Producing and Consuming Messages

You will now use Kafka command line utilities to start producers and consumers for the topic created earlier.

paragraphs.title: 5 - In terminal 1 start a Kafka producer for the weblogs topic
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
kafka-console-producer \
    
```

After starting, the producer will display a prompt `>`. The producer is now ready to accept messages on the command line.

msg.data:
kafka-console-producer \

After starting, the producer will display a prompt >. The producer is now ready to accept messages on the command line.

paragraphs.title: 6 - Publish a test message
paragraphs.text:
%md
Publish a test message to the weblogs topic by typing the message text and then pressing Enter. For example:
```
    > weblog entry 1
    > weblog entry 2
    > test test test
```

msg.data:
Publish a test message to the weblogs topic by typing the message text and then pressing Enter. For example:

    > weblog entry 1
    > weblog entry 2
    > test test test

paragraphs.title: 7 - Open a new terminal window using the command line
paragraphs.text:
%md
Open a new terminal window. To avoid confusion with multiple terminal windows open, start the terminal using the command line instead of the shortcut icon so 
that you can set an alternate title.

```
mate-terminal --title="Kafka Consumer"
```

Adjust the terminal size and location to fit on the window beneath the producer window.

msg.data:
Open a new terminal window. To avoid confusion with multiple terminal windows open, start the terminal using the command line instead of the shortcut icon so
that you can set an alternate title.

mate-terminal --title="Kafka Consumer"

Adjust the terminal size and location to fit on the window beneath the producer window.

paragraphs.title: 8 - Start a Kafka consumer
paragraphs.text:
%md
In the new terminal window, start a Kafka consumer that will read from the beginning of the weblogs topic:

```
kafka-console-consumer \
    
```

After a some startup `INFO` output, you should see the status message you sent using the producer displayed on the consumer's console, such 
as: `weblog entry 1`

msg.data:
In the new terminal window, start a Kafka consumer that will read from the beginning of the weblogs topic:

kafka-console-consumer \

After a some startup INFO output, you should see the status message you sent using the producer displayed on the consumer's console, such
as: weblog entry 1

paragraphs.title: 9 - Restart the weblogs consumer
paragraphs.text:
%md
Press Ctrl+C to stop the weblogs consumer. Restart it, but this time omit the `--from-beginning` option to this command. You should see that no messages are 
displayed.
~~~xml

~~~

msg.data:
Press Ctrl+C to stop the weblogs consumer. Restart it, but this time omit the --from-beginning option to this command. You should see that no messages are
displayed.

paragraphs.title: 10 - Send another test message
paragraphs.text:
%md
Switch back to the producer window and type another test message into the terminal followed by the `Enter` key, for example:
```
    > testing weblog entry 3
```

msg.data:
Switch back to the producer window and type another test message into the terminal followed by the Enter key, for example:

    > testing weblog entry 3

paragraphs.title: 11 - Verify that the consumer has received the message
paragraphs.text:
%md
Return to the consumer window and verify that it now displays the alert message you published from the producer in the previous step.

msg.data: Return to the consumer window and verify that it now displays the alert message you published from the producer in the previous step.

%md

paragraphs.text:

# Solution
---

msg.data: Solution

paragraphs.title: 1 - In terminal 1 display the Kafka topics
paragraphs.text:
%md
Display all Kafka topics to confirm that the new topic you just created is listed

```xml
kafka-topics --list \
    --bootstrap-server localhost:9092
```

msg.data:
Display all Kafka topics to confirm that the new topic you just created is listed

kafka-topics --list \
    --bootstrap-server localhost:9092

paragraphs.title: 2 - Create a Kafka topic for weblogs
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a Kafka topic named weblogs that will contain messages representing lines in Loudacre's web server logs.
```xml
$ kafka-topics --create \
--bootstrap-server localhost:9092 \
--replication-factor 1 \
--partitions 2 \
--topic weblogs
```

You will see the message: Created topic "weblogs".

**Note:** If you previously worked on an exercise that used Kafka, you may get an error here indicating that this topic already exists. You may disregard the error.

msg.data:
Create a Kafka topic named weblogs that will contain messages representing lines in Loudacre's web server logs.

$ kafka-topics --create \
--bootstrap-server localhost:9092 \
--replication-factor 1 \
--partitions 2 \
--topic weblogs

You will see the message: Created topic “weblogs”.

Note: If you previously worked on an exercise that used Kafka, you may get an error here indicating that this topic already exists. You may disregard the error.

paragraphs.title: 3 - List of Kafka topics
paragraphs.text:
%md
Display all Kafka topics to confirm that the new topic you just created is listed
```xml
$ kafka-topics --list \
    --bootstrap-server localhost:9092
```

msg.data:
Display all Kafka topics to confirm that the new topic you just created is listed

$ kafka-topics --list \
    --bootstrap-server localhost:9092

paragraphs.title: 4 - Review the details of the weblogs topic
paragraphs.text:
%md
```xml
$ kafka-topics --describe weblogs \
    --bootstrap-server localhost:9092
```

msg.data:
$ kafka-topics --describe weblogs \
    --bootstrap-server localhost:9092

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Producing and Consuming Messages

msg.data: Producing and Consuming Messages

paragraphs.title: 5 - Start a Kafka producer for the weblogs topic
paragraphs.text:
%md
```xml
$ kafka-console-producer \
--broker-list localhost:9092 \
--topic weblogs
```
After starting, the producer will display a prompt `>`. The producer is now ready to accept messages on the command line.

msg.data:
$ kafka-console-producer \
--broker-list localhost:9092 \
--topic weblogs

After starting, the producer will display a prompt >. The producer is now ready to accept messages on the command line.

paragraphs.title: 6 - Publish a test message
paragraphs.text:
%md
Publish a test message to the weblogs topic by typing the message text and then pressing Enter. For example:
```
> weblog entry 1
> weblog entry 2
> test test test
```

msg.data:
Publish a test message to the weblogs topic by typing the message text and then pressing Enter. For example:

> weblog entry 1
> weblog entry 2
> test test test

paragraphs.title: 7 - Open a new terminal
paragraphs.text:
%md
Open a new terminal window. To avoid confusion with multiple terminal windows open, start the terminal using the command line instead of the shortcut icon so 
that you can set an alternate title.

```
mate-terminal --title="Kafka Consumer"
```

Adjust the terminal size and location to fit on the window beneath the producer window.

msg.data:
Open a new terminal window. To avoid confusion with multiple terminal windows open, start the terminal using the command line instead of the shortcut icon so
that you can set an alternate title.

mate-terminal --title="Kafka Consumer"

Adjust the terminal size and location to fit on the window beneath the producer window.

paragraphs.title: 8 - Start a Kafka consumer
paragraphs.text:
%md
In the new terminal window, start a Kafka consumer that will read from the beginning of the weblogs topic:

```
kafka-console-consumer \
    --bootstrap-server localhost:9092 \
    --topic weblogs \
    --from-beginning
```

After a some startup `INFO` output, you should see the status message you sent using the producer displayed 
on the consumer's console, such as: `weblog entry 1`

msg.data:
In the new terminal window, start a Kafka consumer that will read from the beginning of the weblogs topic:

kafka-console-consumer \
    --bootstrap-server localhost:9092 \
    --topic weblogs \
    --from-beginning

After a some startup INFO output, you should see the status message you sent using the producer displayed
on the consumer's console, such as: weblog entry 1

paragraphs.title: 9 - Restart the weblogs consumer
paragraphs.text:
%md
```xml
kafka-console-consumer \
--bootstrap-server localhost:9092 \
--topic weblogs 
```

msg.data:
kafka-console-consumer \
--bootstrap-server localhost:9092 \
--topic weblogs

paragraphs.title: 10 - Send another test message
paragraphs.text:
%md
Switch back to the producer window and type another test message into the terminal followed by the Enter key, for example:
```
> test weblog entry 3
```

msg.data:
Switch back to the producer window and type another test message into the terminal followed by the Enter key, for example:

> test weblog entry 3

paragraphs.title: 11 - Verify that the consumer has received the message

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Tear Down

msg.data: Tear Down

paragraphs.title: End the consumer process
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
Ctrl+C
```

msg.data: Ctrl+C

paragraphs.title: End the producer process
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
Ctrl+C
```

msg.data: Ctrl+C

paragraphs.title: Exit all terminals
paragraphs.text:
%md
~~~xml
exit
~~~

msg.data: exit
